query: Surrealist Memes: Regression or Progression?

summary.claim: Surrealist Memes can be a driving force in the progression of meme art

perspectives.text: Surrealist memes find cultural forbears in the pre-internet art movements of Dadaism, Surrealism and Pop Art, and they incorporate these styles in their approach to the absurdity of contemporary life.
This ongoing dialogue between various art movements and surreal memes points to the latter’s power as a driving force in the progression of meme art.

By referencing Dali in the same image as Pepe the Frog, surreal memes accomplish another central goal of Pop Art – to mix high and low culture and elevate ordinary, daily items into the world of fine art.
Surrealist memes actively repel audiences by using content that will only resonate with a select group of internet insiders.

summary.claim: Surrealist Memes are devoid of any distinct message and are regressive

perspectives.text: A central criticism of surreal memes is that they don’t have any point, that they are devoid of any distinct message.
The nihilism of surreal memes reveals their regressive nature.
Surrealist memes intentionally lack both sense and clarity, and traffic in absurdity for absurdity’s sake.

perspectives.text: Michael Jackson’s bizarre behavior, namely, his unusual relationships with children, underpinned the public’s suspicions, and a 2005 trial in a Gallup poll reported that most Americans believed that the charges leveled against Jackson were true.

The HBO documentary Leaving Neverland debuted at Sundance in 2018, documenting the accounts of two men who claim that Jackson molested them as boys, continuing the narrative of public response to his alleged abuse.

A former Jackson publicist alleged that Jackson leaked rumors about himself and behaved strangely to build celebrity through spectacle, and Jackson settled the 1993 accusations of sexual abuse out of court and was later acquitted of other accusations laid against him in 2003.

query: Is Harley Quinn a Villain or a Tragic Character?

summary.claim: Harley Quinn is a tragic character due to her abusive relationship with the Joker and her own abusive actions.

perspectives.text: Originally known as psychologist Harleen Quinzel, Harley ends up falling for the Joker, a psychotic patient in Gotham's Arkham Asylum, who is under her care. Despite how the pair may be portrayed within fan art on the internet, their relationship is a toxic and abusive one. For example, in Suicide Squad's New 52 version of her, the Joker pushes Harley off a ledge and into a vat of chemicals to prove her devotion to him. His abuse persists over time; the Joker continuously manipulates Harley into doing his bidding, and he’ll never really love her, because his ultimate obsessive desire is the Batman. All Harley wants to do is put a smile on the Joker’s face, and her many misdeeds are a product of her desire to get the Joker to love her.

It’s difficult to argue for Harley’s mistreatment at the hands of the Joker without acknowledging that she was in a position of power over him – and she abused it. He was under her care as a psychiatrist, and she transgressed the professional boundaries of their relationship. After joining his ranks, Harley had no problem committing crimes for fun, like kidnapping a billionaire because she was bored, robbing a store between fight scenes in Suicide Squad, and beating up Batman and trying to feed him to a tank of piranhas. While it’s pretty clear that Harley is abused by the Joker, it’s not enough to pardon her from her continuous abuse of others.
Harley leaps over all of the red lines that arguably shouldn’t be crossed, and her actions are ruthless, sadistic, and don’t just use murder as a means to an end – she takes pleasure in it.

summary.claim: Harley Quinn is a villain due to her abusive actions and her desire to please the Joker.

perspectives.text: While there are many adaptations of Harley’s character, most of them clearly paint her in a negative light. Paul Dini, who was one of Harley’s original creators, said in an introduction to the 2015 deluxe version of Mad Love : “I don’t think of Mad Love as a victim’s tale, but a cautionary one about what happens when someone loves recklessly, obsessively, and for too long.” This lends itself to the argument that it’s Harley’s choices that get her where she is; namely, in the position of psychologist-turned-serial-killer. She decided to make her villainous bed, and her creators want that to be emphasized throughout her story.

While there are many adaptations of Harley’s character, most of them clearly paint her in a negative light. The show weaves this reasoning through the conflict and outcome, even if the villain sometimes dies. The Enterprise crew will always prefer reasoning – even at the cost of losing – for the sake of goodwill and of spreading the kindness of the human species across the galaxy.

query: The Perspective on the Public Apology

summary.claim: A public apology can open the way for wide-scale rehabilitation.

perspectives.text: A public apology opens the way for wide-scale rehabilitation. It seems that we, as a society, are finally evolving from an environment that has long pushed sexual harassment under the rug to one that acknowledges that to create a brighter future, we must acknowledge our past. No matter why sexual predators and harassers, including talented and powerful men like Charlie Rose, Matt Lauer and Les Moonves, adopted their inappropriate (and maybe even criminal) behavior, their recognition of it is the first step in correcting it and making amends with their victims, families, friends and fans. Society is only as strong as its weakest link. A public apology is an open letter saying the guilty are ready to learn; accepting a public apology says that society is ready to rebuild.

summary.claim: A public apology can be insincere and turn into an appeal for sympathy.

perspectives.text: In some cases, the public apology has come across as more like a non-apology. Disingenuous apologies that read as excuses are merely excuses.
Negative attention is part and parcel of being a public figure, and a public apology can be used as a way to garner sympathy.

query: Open vs. Closed Space Work Environments

summary.claim: Closed office space improves employees’ physical and emotional wellbeing

perspectives.text: Closed office space helps keep germs from spreading between employees and therefore provides workers with increased physical health safety. Having smaller, closed offices with fewer people may be particularly relevant and beneficial to offices that have been enforcing social distancing rules. Not to mention, with less shared office space also means fewer shared office supplies and physical interactions, an obvious plus when it comes to social distancing and lowering the risk of exposure to germs. Physical health aside, closed office space also improves employees’ emotional wellbeing, as they are less exposed to work-related stressors, including the need to appear in constant productivity. Indeed, it’s been suggested that employees working in closed offices tend to experience less age discrimination due to the exhibition of anxiety, cardiac issues and digestive problems caused by the stressful environment they are working in. These employees also experience less neurological problems, like vertigo, brought on by the busy open-space environment.
Closed office space improves employees’ physical and emotional wellbeing

summary.claim: Open office space can inhibit productivity

perspectives.text: In contrast, a completely open office space without any barriers can inhibit productivity. Researchers at Harvard have found that open work environments negatively affect collaboration, actually reducing face-to-face interactions by 70%. Plus, fewer screens or walls between employees, can lead to increased employee interruption, reduced levels of concentration and lower levels of motivation. Since it can take as long as 23 minutes for employees to get back on task and return to a fully engaged state, closed office layouts seem like a smart option to boost (and maintain) levels of concentration.
Open office space can inhibit productivity

Decades of studies support the safety of vaccines.
Doctors have dedicated their lives to studying and practicing medicine, making them a reliable source of information on vaccine safety.

summary.claim: Vaccines may be risky for your kids

perspectives.text: Giving vaccines to children may prevent their immune systems from doing their job, making them more susceptible to getting sick.
The immune system needs to learn how to fight sickness on its own, and vaccines may hinder this process.

query: The Perspective on Ayahuasca: Is it worth trying?

summary.claim: Ayahuasca may help treat depression and has a low risk of addiction.

perspectives.text: Ayahuasca may help treat depression and has a low risk of addiction. For example, a study of the members of an ayahuasca-using Brazilian church (the Unión de Vegetal) showed that the users were overall more confident, cheerful, relaxed, optimistic, outgoing and energetic than controls who don’t use ayahuasca.

Ayahuasca may even help cure addiction. For example, a woman who had been severely alcoholic for over 10 years took ayahuasca in Ecuador and recovered from her addiction, feeling like the psychological causes underlying the addiction were healed.
Preliminary studies have shown reduction of depressive symptoms over the course of two weeks after taking the drug.

summary.claim: Ayahuasca can cause psychotic episodes and has a high risk of negative side effects.

perspectives.text: Taking ayahuasca can cause psychotic episodes, particularly in people with a history of mental illness. These episodes can include paranoia, suicidal ideation, and psychotic delusions for weeks at a time.
Almost everyone who takes ayahuasca gets violently ill, purging throughout their psychedelic trip.
Hallucinogens can cause unpleasant, short-term side effects, like increased heart rate, loss of appetite, sleep disruptions and blood pressure.

query: The Perspective on Physician-Assisted Suicide

summary.text: A PAS system puts the expertise of the doctor and the experience of the patient at the forefront of the issue and views both perspectives rightly as the most credible in a given situation.

When confronted with chronic pain or with diseases that steadily remove our sense of self – or at least the self of whom we are aware – death has proven to be a sensible option taken by sensible people.

The degree to which physical pain and psychological distress can be tolerated is different in all humans. Quality of life judgements are private and personal, thus only the sufferer can make relevant decisions.
The Hippocratic Oath that doctors use as a guide states 'I will neither give a deadly drug to anybody if asked for it, nor will I make a suggestion to this effect.'

query: Is There Life After Death?

summary.claim: There is no life after death

perspectives.text: By definition, death is the cessation of life, and physics professor Sean Carroll contends that life after death is impossible.
Aside from within our dreams and feelings, we don't see or hear of anyone who has supposedly passed on to another world.
Archaeologists and coroners agree that it doesn't look like there is life after death.
The process of body decomposition may be a gruesome one, but it is also telling.

summary.claim: There is life after death

perspectives.text: Research suggests that death may be a more gradual process than previously thought.
Animal cells continued to perform gene expression after the death of the animals in the study.
The researchers believe that their results may extend to humans.
Our bodies may still be alive after they are declared dead.

query: Is Scientology a Religion?

summary.claim: Scientology is a religion

perspectives.text: Scientology shares characteristics with other religions and provides an origin story for the ills of man, and it is arguably no more (or less) far-fetched than those espoused by other religions.
Many argue that Scientology is a religion because it provides useful techniques for self-improvement and helps people to believe they are redeemed.
The church of Scientology provides a motive force to channel innate goodwill and to remind people to exercise it.

summary.claim: Scientology is not a religion

perspectives.text: The church requires payment for its services, which is a characteristic not typically associated with religions.
Scientology’s seeming desire for control over its followers’ lives feels more cultish than religious.
Scientology’s treatment of its followers, including detainment, physical violence, and forced abortions, raises concerns about its legitimacy as a religion.

query: Can the Use of Torture Be Justified?

summary.claim: Torture may be justified in exceptional circumstances to save lives

perspectives.text: Torture can be a means to an end in extreme situations, such as preventing mass murder or saving lives in a ticking-bomb scenario.
Terrorist organizations like Al Qaeda don’t think twice about torturing their captives, and even have a manual to show members exactly what to do.
In times of war, armies may do whatever is necessary to save their country, and suffering from torture can be a facet of that.

summary.claim: Torture is morally wrong and should not be justified under any circumstances

perspectives.text: The use of torture is a rejection of a democracy’s loyalty to abiding by societal rules and values.
Torture may be effective at getting people to talk, but it doesn’t mean they’re telling the truth.
The psychological damage that excessive torture can cause a victim is even worse than the physical damage.

query: Does the Bible Lift Women Up or Tear Them Down?

summary.text: The Bible portrays women in a positive light through stories like Proverbs 31, which extols the virtues of a 'wife of noble character', and highlights their versatility, industriousness, wisdom, physical strength, business acumen, and generosity.
The Bible affirms women's value through its representation of women in leadership positions, such as Deborah, who led the Israelites to victory in battle.
The Bible's portrayal of women is not one of oppression, but rather of women taking initiative and making choices, as seen in the story of Ruth, who chose to follow her heart and find a new home.

query: Should Prostitution be legalized?

summary.claim: Legalizing prostitution can improve the work conditions of sex workers and protect society from a further spreading of HIV/AIDS.

perspectives.text: Prostitution should be legal to ensure sex workers are safe from STI’s and HIV/AIDS.
Legalizing prostitution will improve the work conditions of people who have to go into prostitution for one reason or another and will protect society from a further spreading of HIV/AIDS.
Legalizing prostitution brings sex workers into the fold of society, increasing their sense of belonging, and thereby enhancing their feelings of responsibility toward others.
When we legalise something, it would be easier to monitor it.

summary.claim: Legalizing prostitution would lead to a significant increase in human trafficking and the criminalization of businesses that exploit women and girls.

perspectives.text: Forced prostitution is illegal, which means the law does not protect women/men from being forcibly solicited.
The criminalization of prostitution leaves prostitutes on the fringes of society, making them vulnerable to violence, poverty, and health risks.
Lowering the age of consent (or worse, getting rid of it entirely) legalises, legitimises and brings above ground the many problems that we are fighting underground.
Human trafficking may happen because of its underground nature like what is happening in several countries.

query: Is gun control justified or an infringement of our rights?

summary.claim: Gun control is justified as it can make the world safer by limiting guns from getting into the wrong hands.

perspectives.text: Gun control laws are not proving effective in cities like Chicago where there are bans on assault rifles and high-capacity magazines, and where gun shops were banned until 2012, and the city suffers from rising gun and gang violence.

Universal background checks on private and gun show sales, an issue that survivors of the February 2018 Parkland massacre helped push legislators to prioritize, can help prevent criminals and the mentally ill from getting guns.
Installing safety devices on guns would minimize accidental gun deaths, especially of and by children.

summary.claim: Gun control is an infringement of our rights as it infringes on the fundamental individual right to bear arms.

perspectives.text: Gun ownership exercises a fundamental individual right under the U.S. Constitution.
No wonder gun owners take it personally when gun control laws appear to infringe on this right, thus impeding efforts to acquire firearms and protect themselves and their families.
There’s the risk that certain proposed background checks may require government databases to keep gun owners’ personal information indefinitely.

query: Are tattoos a welcome form of self-expression or a cause of regret?

summary.claim: Tattoos can be a form of self-expression and enhance self-esteem.

perspectives.text: Tattoos enhance self-esteem and are a right that many people around the world still don’t have – and are fighting for.
A Texas Tech University study found that college-age women with four or more tattoos reported higher levels of self-esteem than anyone else in the study.
Tattoos help people feel comfortable in their own skin.

summary.claim: Tattoos can be a cause of regret and lead to negative meanings.

perspectives.text: A study found that nearly one in three people with a tattoo regret getting one.
Many get tattoos impulsively, and that spur-of-the-moment decision is often one of the biggest predictors of tattoo regret.
Symbols, which many people choose as a tattoo, change over time, or are appropriated for different agendas of various ideologies.

query: Are Antidepressants a Good Solution?

summary.claim: Antidepressants can be a good solution for depression

perspectives.text: Antidepressants are a non-invasive way to restore the balance of neurotransmitters in the brain, which can lead to improved mood and reduced symptoms of depression.
Studies show that 60-70% of depressed patients who take antidepressants respond positively, with symptoms eventually remitting.

summary.claim: Antidepressants may not be a good solution for depression

perspectives.text: The risk of relapse after discontinuing antidepressant medication is high, and the relapse rate is even higher for people taking stronger antidepressants.
Fifty to 60% of antidepressant users experience significant side effects, and the possibility of suicidal thoughts is a potential side effect of almost every antidepressant.

query: Does Homework Help or Hinder Learning?

summary.claim: Homework can help students learn and develop important life skills

perspectives.text: Homework assignments give parents a window into what their child is studying. Parental involvement has been shown to be significant for scholastic success. Therefore, homework assignments serve as a positive and productive way to bring parents and children together.

The main aim of education is to prepare us for the rest of lives. Homework is teaching us a key skill that we will need in the future. When we do homework we are learning to work on our own, the discipline to get the work done without the teacher’s prompting, and when we come up against difficulties we learn how to overcome them without our teacher’s help.

summary.claim: Homework can hinder students’ learning and cause stress

perspectives.text: We all need some time to ourselves. School already takes up a lot of time and it is necessary to have time which does not involve concentrating on learning. Education is not the only important activity in everyone’s day; physical activity, play, and time with family are just as important as all teach life skills just in different ways.

Way before the coronavirus hit, elementary school kids were already more stressed-out than any generation before them. While there are numerous causes for such stress, the burden of homework plays a large part.

More than a decade ago a 2007 study by Metlife already reported that 28% of students in grades 3-6 were “often” or “very often” stressed out by homework and, since then, stress among children has only grown.

query: Should Women Serve in Combat Units?

summary.claim: Women should be allowed to serve in combat units

perspectives.text: Women should be allowed to choose how they fight for their country based on their strengths, and their inclusion in combat units can be an asset to their team.
Having exceptional women in the army is crucial to the way we want to see society, and their inclusion in combat units can help to address broader attitudes toward gender norms.
Women can take the heat and are not in need of protection from the difficulties of combat units.

summary.claim: Women should not be allowed to serve in combat units

perspectives.text: The military status quo should not be messed with, as it has been working thus far, and the addition of women to combat units can add liabilities and complexities.
The inclusion of women in combat units can pose a threat to the safety of all soldiers, and enemies do not care about political correctness.
The introduction of quotas for women in politics is not a suitable solution, as it does not ensure effective representation of what all women want or the means for change.

query: Is Color Perception a Universal Human Experience?

summary.claim: Color Perception is a Universal Human Experience

perspectives.text: Many cultures see and talk about color very differently than the Western world, and yet, people tend to categorize colors into the same basic groupings, suggesting that color perception is a universal human experience.
The vast majority of humans have the same basic perceptual abilities, with only a few exceptions, such as color blindness, which is relatively rare.

summary.claim: Color Perception is not a Universal Human Experience

perspectives.text: Some cultures, like the Candoshi of Peru, do not have a word for the over-arching concept of color, and their color perception may be different from that of other cultures.
The existence of color blindness, which affects a small percentage of the population, suggests that color perception is not a universal human experience.

query: Is Obesity a Disease?

summary.claim: Is Obesity a Disease?

positive_claims.text: Obesity should be identified as a disease to allow for cost-effective treatments and prevention of associated diseases.
Defining obesity as a disease can relieve the stigma surrounding it and encourage individuals to seek medical assistance.

negative_claims.text: Obesity should not be classified as a disease, as it may lead to over-reliance on pharmacological treatments and diminish an individual's sense of control over their weight.
Terminating obesity treatment can be seen as a form of mercy killing, which is morally and ethically wrong.

summary.claim: Is Obesity a Disease?

positive_claims.text: Obesity can be treated with a variety of interventions, including consultations with a nutritionist, physical therapy, or bariatric surgery.

negative_claims.text: The classification of obesity as a disease may not address the underlying causes of obesity, which can be complex and influenced by genetic or metabolic factors.

query: Sigmund Freud: A timeless genius or overrated?

summary.claim: Sigmund Freud’s groundbreaking work in developing psychoanalysis laid the foundation for modern psychology.

perspectives.text: Freud’s pioneering ideas sought to look deep into the human psyche and seek insights into the sources of people’s emotional conflicts.
Freud’s exploration into the complexities of motivation, his examination of human sexuality, as well as the inspiration behind the creative process, inspired many philosophers, scholars, and artists.
Freud’s techniques of dream analysis and free association profoundly impacted the Surrealists, like Salvadore Dali, among others.

Freud’s ability to clearly express ideas for people across the sciences and the arts is a testament to Freud’s unique ability to bridge the gap between intricate psychological concepts and the broader artistic community.
Freud’s work in developing psychoanalysis laid the foundation for modern psychology, and his techniques of dream analysis and free association continue to be studied and used today.

summary.claim: Some critics argue that Freud’s theories have limited applicability.

perspectives.text: Freud’s focus on sexual explanations for psychological incidents has been seen as simplistic.
Freud’s theories, particularly those related to sexuality, psychosexual stages of development, and gender – specifically the female identity – are outdated and reflect the biases of his era.
Freud’s theories, like women’s “rape fantasy,” were developed during a time when societal attitudes towards sexuality – and femininity in general – were much more conservative (or downright sexist),
Freud’s theories have been criticized for being overly focused on individual psychology and neglecting external factors such as social and cultural influences.

query: Do Professional Athletes Deserve Their Inflated Salaries?

summary.claim: Professional athletes deserve their inflated salaries due to the health risks they take and the time they spend training.

perspectives.text: Professional athletes sacrifice important aspects of their lives, especially their health and family. For instance, during each season of any professional sport, there are away games that keep players from their families. More significant, though, is that players put their bodies in danger daily. Physical injury can leave professional athletes handicapped or disabled for the rest of their lives; NFL players who experience multiple concussions can suffer from progressive degenerative disease that causes dementia and depression.

Professional athletes put their bodies at risk of permanent damage, without being paid. Hurting your knee might leave you limping for the rest of your life. Suffering concussions can cause dementia and depression, not to mention CTE.

The IAAF has a duty to provide a safe environment for their athletes. The sports medical team is responsible for preventing illness and injury, clearly something that is caused by harsh training. As do all those who are involved in sports. These athletes only exist in a professional capacity because bodies created the positions for the athletes to exist.
Professional athletes competing for money rather than for excellence will take the soul and magic out of sports, ruining it in the long run – for athletes and for fans.

summary.claim: Professional athletes do not deserve their inflated salaries because of the financial burden on their families and the negative impact on the sport.

perspectives.text: While the highest paid athletes draw more attention, the truth is that most athletes are fairly paid. Plus, we tend to forget that published professional athletes’ salaries are gross salaries. While these may seem huge, so are the deductions from them.

The large amounts of money invested in professional sports in recent years has the potential to drain the true meaning from sports. Given athletes’ large salaries, more youngsters want to become professional athletes – but for the big money, not for the love of the game.

People argue that paying college athletes will help create a sense of financial awareness for them. However, in reality, poor investments, trusting unethical financial advisors and lavish spending habits are some of the main reasons professional athletes find themselves broke after they retire.

The mythical status of all professional athletes is long gone. Lance Armstrong and Tiger Woods are just a couple examples of professional athletes who are no longer seen as being role models for youngsters. Today, we know much more about our sports heroes’ lives, for better and for worse.

Corporate culture has creeped into some sports leagues. This trend holds a significant effect on players’ salaries: It helps some athletes get oversized contracts while increasing income inequality between the majority of athletes.

If the world wants to pay people to perform and compete for them, then once that offer is made they have a moral duty to ensure that work is safe, since they are culpable in creating that work. Moreover, we give the IAAF power in the promise that by giving up localised power of judgement over sport, they can better protect athletes and creating a fairer sporting environment.

Take Scottie Pippen, who, despite being a vital asset that lifted both Michael Jordan and the Chicago Bulls, played most of the 1990s under what is considered one of the worst contracts in NBA history. In fact, some pro athletes in minor league baseball don’t even make minimum wage.

query: The Perspective on Single-Payer Health Care

summary.claim: Single-payer health care can improve health outcomes for the middle class and small business owners and workers.

perspectives.text: The current system provides government-sponsored health care for the poor and elderly through Medicare and Medicaid, while most workers in large corporations receive health care as part of their compensation as required under Obamacare. Government-provided health care would make it easier for entrepreneurs to leave their jobs and start their own businesses, since they would not be putting their families’ health care at risk. It would make it easier to hire workers early on, since employees would be more willing to take a risk working at a new firm knowing that health care is provided. And if the business takes off, it would no longer face the threat of the employer mandate once it crosses a certain threshold, which Obamacare set at 50 workers.

Private-sector investment will provide crucial training for health professionals, infrastructure, and resources to improve maternal and child health care. Providing affordable maternal care acts as a means for promoting gender equality, and empowerment. Jacaranda Health operate on a business model, meeting the demand, and need, for affordable and high-quality maternal care in East Africa. Through mobile clinics and new maternity hospitals Jacaranda Health is empowering women and children.

query: Social Welfare: Do its advantages outweigh its disadvantages?

summary.text: Social welfare programs can brighten the future for poverty-stricken kids, ultimately halting the cycle of poverty in families at risk. A recent study from Georgetown University and University of Chicago found that Mexico’s Prospera – a cash-transfer system conditional on parents sending their children to school and staying up-to-date with doctors’ appointments – led to greater increases in children’s educational attainment long-term. These children grew up to work an average of nine more hours a week than their counterparts who weren’t enrolled in the program, in addition to earning higher hourly wages. Another study found that kids who were covered by Medicaid later earned more money and required less welfare assistance as adults. Poverty can be traumatic for children, and welfare helps the next generation become less reliant on government support.
Aside from adults, social welfare can also brighten the future for poverty-stricken kids, ultimately halting the cycle of poverty in families at risk.

query: Obama’s Legacy: Mission Accomplished or Mission Impossible?

summary.text: Obama’s presidency witnessed significant strides toward a more multicultural America that celebrates diversity. Top policy positions went to people of all colors, classes and creeds. Obama appointed more female and ethnically diverse judges than any president in history, including the Supreme Court’s first Latina Judge. He was the first president to introduce Hindu customs into the White House, or to wish Persian Americans a happy new year in Farsi. He also strengthened LGTB rights, paving the way for marriage equality and anti-discrimination legislation. No president better reflected America’s diversity, or honored it so single-mindedly as he.

Obama’s watershed victories on environmental protections, health care, equality, reproductive rights and financial reform were, in large part, accomplished through executive power – by issuing executive orders and regulations. Besides making it exceedingly easy for successors to simply “ tear up ” these laws, another unappealing side effect of Obama’s executive bulldozing is that it invites his successors to do the same. Take the Iran nuclear deal, which was signed by the US at the tail end of Obama’s presidency, yet has now been made a memory thanks to President Trump’s recent exit from the deal. The Paris climate change agreement is now as good as gone, as is the order that allowed transgender troops to serve in the military.

query: Is Working from Home All It’s Cracked Up To Be?

summary.claim: Working from home can provide significant savings in transportation costs and access to affordable food.

perspectives.text: For individuals, working from home means significant savings in transportation costs, like gas and automobile upkeep, and access to affordable (and arguably, healthier) food from their own kitchens.
Time economy for telecommuters is also a distinct advantage – hours not spent commuting can be applied to work, household upkeep, or even exercise or sleep.

Work-from-home opportunities increase overall household incomes by providing opportunities for individuals who are not able to arrive to traditional jobs, like parents with young children, retirees, and the disabled.

summary.claim: Working from home can be detrimental to achieving a healthy work-life balance and may not be suitable for all personality types.

perspectives.text: For a workaholic, working from home is roughly equivalent to conducting an AA meeting in a distillery – the tools to feed your addiction are precariously close by.
Those who dream of working in their pajamas often meet the fretful reality that they were as productive in their waking hours as they were in their sleep.
